I have had this for about a month and really like it. It works consistently both with the app and Alexa. Installation was easy too.
The best feature is that it is more energy efficient than competitive switches. I bought a Leviton switch initially (DW15S-1BZ) and found it disconcerting how warm it was. I bought this TP-Link switch and installed it in another room to compare. This switch is cool to the touch. It uses a little bit of power even when the light is off, but not a noticeable amount. The TP-Link Switch is about 8 degrees warmer than the ambient room temperature. In comparison, the Leviton switch was 20 degrees warmer which is warm enough to notice.
My biggest compliant is that it requires you to push the lower section to both turn it on and off. When you go to turn it on, you expect to be able to push the top. Nothing happens there though (you can't depress it, so you know something's not right). When you push the lower section, it will toggle on/off. It works great, but isn't as intuitive as the Leviton switch which allows you to use the upper/lower section to turn it on/off. Even so, you adapt quickly. I plan to buy more of these despite this shortcoming.
I attached some photos showing temperature measurements on this switch and another one. Both are off. It shows this one is much cooler because it is more energy efficient. Temperatures were taken using a Fluke IR temperature sensor. I also took current and voltage waveforms using a Keithley DMM7510 (see various attached screen hots). I found the power to be about 0.5 W when the switch is off or 1.62 W when the switch is on. This was 3 times less power when the switch was off when compared to the Leviton switch (1.86W whether on or off)

3. Cover your work with electrical tape and you're done.

First of all, the control app for this company's devices is great. I don't have a lot of experience with smart home devices in general, but I had no trouble at all setting up these bulbs and the interface is very intuitive. I was playing around with them using my phone within 5 minutes of opening the box. It interfaces easily with Google Home, with only a small degree of lag time, so I was also able to issue voice commands relatively quickly. I like when I don't have to fight with technology, and I definitely did not have to fight any step of the way with these light bulbs.
The light bulbs themselves have two settings, "white mode" and "color mode." The default when you set it up is white mode, and they are VERY bright bulbs, maybe equivalent to 100W incandescent, so if you're an idiot like me and you are looking at it when you flip the switch, it can be a somewhat jarring experience. One thing to note up front is that "color mode" is about half as bright, maybe equivalent to a 60W bulb. The first time I switched from "white" to "color" I was a bit surprised by how much dimmer it seemed in comparison.
"White mode" only has a single slider for brightness. This is, I suppose, to be expected. The color temperature is highly on the blue end, so the light is very artificial and institutional feeling, like overhead fluorescent tubes at a hospital. I like to use bulbs like this in rooms I need a lot of light, like the kitchen. Most of the time though I strongly prefer "soft" white to "daylight," and so it would be really nice if there was a way to switch between soft and daylight, or have a color temperature slide from 3000K to 5000K. Something which would temper the harshness. Of course, this is just my opinion; many people might strongly prefer "daylight" style light. The brightness slide reduces the brightness down to perhaps a 20W bulb equivalent amount of light, but doesn't change the overall color much; it's still very bright white even at dim settings.
The "color mode" I had a lot more fun with. As I mentioned, it's not nearly as bright as the white mode, which for me was a plus. The color selector is the form of a ring which covers just about any color possible. Obviously the color of the bulb doesn't match the color on the wheel, but you can get a very broad variety. There is also a saturation slider which gives you even more options. So in concert with my comment above about the white mode being too bright, I usually find a nice color of yellow and slide the saturation down to get more akin to candlelight, and it works nice in a floor lamp. Color mode though is obviously for accent lighting, it's not bright enough to reasonably expect to light a room unless you've got multiples.
Given that most overhead light fixtures have sockets for two (or more) bulbs, the utility of these bulbs is limited, unless you want to "temper" the light in the room with a complimentary color (for instance). They are really much better for table, floor, and accent lights with a single socket. In this application, the color mode is a lot more fun, and you have a lot more options with how you light your room. I can already envision applications for having different kinds of ambient light for watching movies, playing games, reading, etc.
There is a third feature associated with these, which allow you to create programs, as well as having a few preset color-changing programs, but I haven't played around with it at all. I can't exactly envision a use for this feature for myself, so I can't opine on them too much.
Overall though these things are a GREAT value, and have a LOT of features. I would hope that they'd be able to fit in a color temperature feature for "white mode" with a latter software update, but that'd be the difference between a 4 star and a 5 star product as far as I'm concerned.

I have installed six Wemo outlets and two Wemo single-pole switches. At first, I was quite frustrated with Wemo - connectivity was always problematic. Devices kept dropping out, and then dropping back in, with no real detectable pattern. This was particularly an issue when I was not home - using the Wemo app via cellular connection was a form of Russian Roulette.
I then performed an already-planned upgrade to my entire local-area network (LAN). After updating/upgrading my LAN and WiFi hardware, I have found that the Wemo devices are now rock-steady, even when accessing them while on the road. I can only conclude that my WiFi network was to blame.
My original LAN had an eight-year-old DOCSIS 2.0 modem, and a similarly aged 10/100/1000 router. From the router, I ran three small six-year-old b/g/n access points throughout my house - it was the only way I could get enough signal strength in every room.
My new LAN has a DOCSIS 3.1 modem, a gigabit router (with its WiFi function disabled), and a single n/ac three-band 1.6 Gbit WiFi access point that puts out enough signal to cover the whole house (the access point has six antennas!).
As stated, after switching all of the Wemo devices over to a "modern" WiFi network, the Wemo switches and outlets have worked flawlessly.
In messing with the Wemo devices, here are some lessons I have learned:
1) Use a single WiFi router (or access point) that puts out lots of signal.
2) After installing all of your devices, uninstall and then re-install the Wemo app on your phone. This clears any old settings and/or cache values that may create conflicts. Uninstalling/re-installing seems to work better at "clearing the table" than just clearing cache and data in the app manager.
3) Specific to the switches (the device reviewed here): The reset button is a little depressable bar located under and at the bottom of the "regular" (on/off) button. To install the switch on your WiFi network, depress this reset button long enough such that you'll see the indicator LED on the on/off button cycle through all of the available colors (starting with red, switching to white, then blue, then finally red again). When the LED is flashing red, let go, and then wait for the LED to start flashing blue. This can take up to ~ 45 secs to execute. When the LED is flashing blue, the device is ready for pairing with your WiFi network (Wemo's own instructions regarding this process are rather nebulous).

First off, this package of switches represents the 20th smart switch I have installed into my house. Using the Smart Life app on my phone, getting one of these installed only took 15 minutes. Assuming multiple on the same breaker, doing them all at once, consider about another 10 minutes for each switch.
WiFi Note - These only 'work' on a 2.4Ghz WiFi. What that means is that if you try to configure using your phone which sees the WiFi of 2.4Ghz and 5Ghz and only shows a single name, you will encounter problems if you have 'intra-station' traffic disabled. If you have 'intra-station' traffic enabled (typical default in the USA) and your WiFi use the same name, you shouldn't have any issues. Although a proper WiFi stack on a device *should* work even when both 2.4Ghz and 5Ghz use the same name, enough devices don't work right that I no longer recommend that configuration unless you have tested your devices and it is helping you achieve higher speeds.
Back to the switches - These switches are great quality, I haven't had any issues with them. If your house is older than about 1975 in the USA and hasn't been rewired, these aren't the right product for you because a neutral wire is required. Aside from that, turn off the breaker, put the common wire at the top of your existing switch to the common/load terminal of this switch, and connect each of the two travelers (next to each other vertically and on opposite sides of your existing switch). It doesn't matter which traveler is connected to which side, because that is how 3-way switches work.

First off, I have to say that I really don't like the warm white color light and always have disliked it. So my review of these bulbs is slanted by the fact that the white color isn't tunable to my liking.
The bulbs arrived safely and on time. I ignored the instructions to download yet another app. Each of the four bulbs started flashing immediately and connected to the Tuya "Smart Life" app I already had installed on my iPad, even through a closed double-paned glass door to the outside. I didn't have to move the router or iPad closer to get them to connect. Google Home found them in no time as well. If you need instructions, get out your reading glasses because light grey type on white glossy paper isn't a great choice for reading, fashionable though it may look.
The lights worked as smart bulbs do, even in tandem with a smart switch. (First, you have to turn the smart switch on, then the particular bulb.) Scenes from the "Smart Life" app worked, except for music, but it may be that there's not enough bass in Debussy for that to function properly.
I had been debating whether to get smart bulbs for my house. I'll probably keep the one on the patio, and I may get a smart daylight (5000K+) bulb for one or two locations, but I'm much more likely to use smart sockets, switches, or outlets with regular LED bulbs. I'll give away the rest to a friend who likes the warm white color. I suppose I just don't need the entertainment value of changing colors except in entertaining areas, when entertaining. With IFTTT integration I may figure out a scenario in which I want bulbs to change color to notify me of something, eventually. I am not opposed to smart technology; I have many smart devices and I see the value, especially as I am aging. Smart devices will enable me to keep my independence much longer. I'm just not convinced, for me, of the value of these particular smart bulbs. On the other hand, if you live with others, you may want to know if they are coming home, or you may want a countdown to turn off your child's light at night, or some other scenario, and if that is the case, smart bulbs may be useful for you. They may also be useful if you live in an apartment and want smart lights without installing new switches.
I was able to get a fairly close approximation of daylight white by changing the color to blue and decreasing the saturation to 4%. Had the white been tunable, I probably would have given the bulbs five stars. It's not the bulbs' fault that AI can't figure out classical music, or that I'm capable of entertaining myself without the lights changing color.

selection4_selection2_selection3:
Sound quality is the best I've heard on a speaker of this size!!! Definitely worth paying a little extra for this one over the 2nd generation model. I'm not going to discuss the functionality as there's tons of info already out there. One important note: If you set up the Alexa app on your phone, IT WILL IMPORT ALL OF YOUR PHONE CONTACTS. I didn't think I gave it permission to do so but Alexa did indeed import my contacts! You may have read stories how, WITHOUT YOUR KNOWLEDGE, Alexa can record what's being said in your home and then send it to ANY or ALL of those contacts! Yikes! And, I won't want any of my kids to accidentally send messages to or call people on my contact list. So, if you want to keep your contacts from Alexa and prevent that from happening here's how I did it:
Before installiing the Alexa app on your phone, export your contacts to a file and save it for later. Then, go back to the phone and delete those contacts (don't worry, you'll import them back in later). Now, install the Alexa app on your phone and go through the set up process. At some point, you'll have the option to allow Alexa to automatically import any additions to your contacts. Please "disable" that option. After you're done with the installation, you'll notice there are no contacts in your Alexa app! Now, you can import your contacts back into your phonebook using the file that you initially created and you're good to go!
If you already installed the app but want to delete your contacts from Alexa, it's not too late. Simply export your phone contacts to a file and save for later. Then, delete the contacts from your phone. Now, open the Alexa app and click "Contacts." On the Contacts page, click on "Import Contacts" and enable it by moving the button to the right side. This will cause Alexa to replace your existing contacts with the now empty phonebook. After a few minutes, your Alexa contacts will be gone. Go back and disable "Import Contacts" to prevent Alexa from importing them in the future. You can now import the contact file that you created back into your phone.
Of course there may be some contacts you do want to use with Alexa. I simply added them manually by clicking "Add Contact."
I hope this info is helpful as I wasn't able to find an easy way to manage Alexa contacts.

I researched quite a bit for a light strip system that would handle 75 ft. All pretty much was going to need to be soldered with a 12V 5a power source and a injection needed and additional power source. Most systems could only handle 32ft before needing another power source. Then a controller was needed to integrate with Echo or wifi or ST. Was getting costly for the amount of work. I then came across this system and I thought what gives?? 24v 4a system, the math works out for the 65ft. Reviews were hit or miss, but most had to do with issues out of the box. This system had everything I needed except integration with Smartthings, but I can get around that with the Alexa Enabled Magic Home Skill and Wifi controller through IFTTT.
The set up was a breeze, and runs in Parallel. If you want to run them in series you will need to get a male 4 prong RGB connector since both ends of the lights have female connector attachments on them. I needed an additional 10 ft, so I opted with purchasing 2 systems and cutting one of them to extend the additional 10 ft. I was able to use a solderless connector to connect the two strips. There is no issue with brightness loss from the extension.
The adhesive tape on the back is Great!! Easy to place and strong hold. The remote is limited, but the Magic Home app is decent with great color scales. Lights sync up to music from the speaker of your phone through the app, but I have not explored this use much. There might be a way to use music through Echo. Last.....These lights are BRIGHT!! I run them at 30% Dim and they are bright enough. At 100% they are great!. This is a great system for the price, especially for long runs and distances.
Only two down sides: 1) Remote is limited (but not needed) 2) Connectors are not very tight and come apart easily (Lights to Wifi controller to Power supply) are the weak connections. Tape or zip ties can solve this issue.
